LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

In 

Republic of Tajikistan 
 
The  proposed  Microfinance  Systems  Development  Program 
(MSDP) comprises two loans from the Asian Development Fund's 
resources:  (i)  a  policy  loan  of  $4  million  equivalent  to  support 
policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  reforms  for  microfinance;  and  (ii)  an 
investment  loan  of  $4  million  equivalent  to  help  transform 
nongovernmental  organization  (NGO)  microcredit  programs  into 
licensed and regulated microfinance institutions (MFIs). 
 
Poverty Intervention. Thematic: Gender 
 
Classified as category C 
 
 
Tajikistan  has  recently  made  great  progress  in  moving  toward  a 
market-based  economy. 
the  past  3  years,  economic 
development  and  transition  have  accelerated,  yet  the  poverty 
incidence remains high. Recent surveys estimated that in 2002 as 
much as 80% of the population is poor.  
 
The commercial banking sector, in an early stage of development, 
cannot  meet  the  needs  of  micro-  and  small  enterprises  (MSEs) 
and  poor  households.  Rural  areas  remain  largely  unserved  by 
banks. In contrast, Tajikistan has seen the emergence of a highly 
active and potentially effective microfinance sector. By the end of 
2002, around 17 NGOs were carrying out lending activities, which 
are  generally  funded  through  international  grant  assistance.  The 
loans target rural microenterprises and women, and the poor.

The  objective  of  the  investment  loan  is  to  expand  the  outreach 
and sustainability of MFIs that serve MSEs and poor households 
by 
licensed, 
regulated  financial  institutions.  The  scope  has  four  components: 
(i) legal and regulatory framework, (ii) establishment of MFIs, (iii) 
institutional  strengthening  of  NBT  and  MFIs,  and  (iv)  project 
management.  The  scope  is  nationwide,  with  the  geographical 
focus dependent on where the selected NGOs willing to become 
MFIs have microfinance operations. 
 
The total cost of the investment project is $5.31 million equivalent. 
ADB  will  finance  $4  million  equivalent  from  ADF  resources;  the 
Government will finance $390,000; NGOs and/or MFIs, $700,000; 
and clients/beneficiaries, $220,000.

 Loan Amount and Terms  A  loan  of  SDR2.934  million  ($4  million  equivalent)  is  proposed 
from ADF resources. The loan will have an amortization period of 
32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8 years,  with  an  interest

thereafter.  
 
The arrangements include the MPSC, National Bank of Tajikistan 
(NBT), PMU, and TWG. The MPSC, chaired by NBT, will include 
representatives  of  key  government  agencies,  NBT,  and  NGOs, 
and will be responsible for overall coordination of the project and 
serve  as  the  main  forum  for  discussion  of  microfinance  policy. 
NBT is the Executing Agency and will coordinate project activities, 
ensure proper reporting, and serve as the focal point for ADB and 
NGOs/MFIs.  NBT  will  appoint  a  project  director  and  establish  a 
PMU  to  implement  project  activities.  TWG  will  lead  in  identifying 
key  issues  in  microfinance  development  and  the  creation  of  an 
enabling  legal  and  regulatory  environment;  facilitate  cooperation 
among key agencies and NGOs; and address operational issues 
related to microfinance and MFIs. 
 
The investment project will be implemented over 4 years and the 
loan completely drawn down in 5 years. 
 
Procurement  of  goods  and  services  will  be  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. A total of 86 person-months of 
consulting  services/technical  assistance,  comprising  14  person-
months  of  international  and  72  person-months  of  domestic 
expertise,  will  be  provided  by  an  international  consulting  firm 
recruited  in  accordance  with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants by ADB and its Borrowers using the quality and cost-
based selection method.

Benefits And Impact 

MSDP  will  provide  an  improved  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory 
environment  that  will  allow  the  formalization  of  unregulated 
financial  activity.  An  enabling  environment  combined  with 
substantial  capacity  building  will  result  in  the  transformation  of 
existing  NGO  microcredit  programs  into  licensed  and  regulated 
MFIs.  New  ones  may  also  be  established  to  increase  diversity 
within  the  financial  sector.  Through  the  licensing  of  at  least  two 
deposit-taking  MFIs,  the  number  of  borrowers  will  increase  from 
15,000 to 38,000 in five years, and increase MFIs’ loan portfolio to 
$4  million.  Formalized  microcredit  provided  through  viable  MFIs 
will  benefit  thousands  of  MSEs,  which  rely  mainly  on  their  own 
savings to fund their activities. With improved, constant access to 
loans, MSEs can expand, benefiting the owners and their families 
directly, and the broader economy indirectly. MSEs, the poor, and 
rural  dwellers  will  benefit  directly  from  accessible  facilities  to 
safeguard savings.

Technical Assistance 

  

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  two  proposed 
loans to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Microfinance Systems Development Program (MSDP). 
The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Institutional Strengthening of 
Microfinance  Systems,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loans,  I,  acting  under  the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 

II. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES1 

A. 

Macroeconomic Context 

Since  independence  in  1991,  Tajikistan  has  been  in  transition  to  a  market-oriented 
2. 
economy.  The  macroeconomic  situation  has  steadily  improved,  with  significant  growth  and 
stabilization supported by structural reforms.2 Economic growth gained  momentum  after 1997, 
although  the  Russian  crisis  caused  a  downturn  in  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  from 
5.3%  in  1998  to  3.7%  in  1999.  Following  increased  cotton  and  aluminum  production,  which 
together account for about two thirds of export earnings, GDP growth rebounded 8.3% in 2000, 
10.0% in 2001, and 8.0% in 2002. Inflation stabilized at 27.5% in 1999, but slid to 38.6% in 2001 
due  to  external  factors  and  problematic  implementation  of  monetary  policy.  The  International 
Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates inflation to decline to 13% in 2002, and further to 5% by 2004.  
 
3. 
Tajikistan  is  highly  dependent  on  foreign  trade,  with  exports  constituting  70%  of  GDP. 
The  external  current  account  deficit  increased  from  6.6%  of  GDP  in  2000  to  7.0%  in  2001. 
Gross foreign exchange reserves stood at 2.1 months of imports at the end of 2001. 
 
4. 
During  the  May  2001  Consultative  Group  Meeting  a  financing  gap  of  $26 million  was 
estimated  in  the  budget  for  2002.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  agreed  to  provide 
assistance for the ongoing transition reform agenda, particularly in rural finance and agriculture. 
Tajikistan has a high publicly guaranteed external debt burden equivalent to 87% of GDP, due 
to large nonconcessional bilateral borrowings. IMF imposed a debt ceiling of 3% of GDP on the 
externally  financed  Public  Investment  Program  beginning  in  2002.  Under  the  $128-million 
Poverty  Reduction  Growth  Facility  (PRGF)  (1999–2001),  the  Government  failed  to  meet  all  its 
structural  adjustment  targets  and  misreported  external  debt  levels.  IMF  introduced  a  staff-
monitored program from October 2001. An $87-million 3-year PRGF was signed in December 
2002.  
 
5. 
Tajikistan, one of the poorest republics of the former Soviet Union (FSU), stands out as 
one of the poorest countries in Asia. Despite progress made since independence, overall living 
standards have deteriorated drastically, particularly in rural areas, due to the civil war, general 
economic  contraction,  and  loss  of  social  services.  Tajikistan  ranks  110th  among  174  states 
based  on  the  human  development  index,  with  an  estimated  per  capita  gross  national  product

 2

 

 

(GNP)  of  $290.  The  1999  Tajik  Living  Standards  Survey  indicates  that  over  80%  of  the  6.2 
million people live in poverty, with about 30% ”very poor” and nearly 20% ”extremely poor.”3  
 
6. 
Poverty in rural areas, where 75% of the people live, is more acute than in urban areas. 
The proportion of people living in extreme poverty is 23.4% in rural areas, and 18.6% in urban 
areas. Only 56% of able-bodied citizens are formally employed, leaving nearly half the working 
population  to  look  for  income-generating  opportunities  on  their  own.  Poor  people  engage  in  a 
number  of  such  activities  to  make  ends  meet.  In  the  poorest  households,  the  single  largest 
source of income accounts for only a third of total household income.  
 
7. 
The  most  vulnerable  groups  include  pensioners,  the  disabled,  single-headed  family 
households,  families  with  five  or  more  children,  teachers,  doctors,  and  the  unemployed.  An 
important finding of the Tajik Living Standards Survey was that financial hardship is not limited 
to  the  poorest.  Over  25%  of  all  households  have  sold  assets  and  about  33%  have  borrowed 
money to buy food. 
 
Poverty  has  a  gender  dimension.  While  poverty  incidence  does  not  vary  between  men 
8. 
and women, the transition has affected women disproportionately due to (i) the collapse of the 
social  allowance  and  services;  (ii)  women’s  income  being  four  times  lower  than  men’s;  (iii) 
female-headed households having less access to land, irrigation, and agriculture; (iv) women’s 
unemployment being marginally higher than men’s;4 and (v) women being employed mainly in 
the  low-paid  sectors  such  as  agriculture,  education,  and  health.  The  Government  has  set 
poverty  reduction  as  its  primary  objective,  requiring  a  comprehensive  and  long-term  strategy. 
The National Poverty Reduction Strategy, endorsed by Parliament on 24 June 2002, focuses on 
(i)  accelerated,  socially  fair,  labor-intensive,  and  export-oriented  economic  growth;  (ii)  efficient 
and  fair  provision  of  basic  social  services;  (iii)  targeted  support  to  the  poorest  groups  of  the 
population; and (iv) efficient governance and improvement in security. 
 
Microfinance  reduces  poverty.  The  small  number  of  micro-  and  small  enterprises 
9. 
(MSEs),  poor  households,  and  rural  dwellers  who  have  access  to  microcredit  have  benefited 
from increased and stable incomes. Microfinance is limited to microcredit. Access to small loans 
provides  working  capital  to  simple  businesses  that  need cash.  In  a  very  poor  country  such  as 
Tajikistan,  where  people  have  little  savings,  credit  is  one  of  the  few  sources  of  investment 
capital.  Microcredit 
its  provision  must  be 
institutionalized. New financial services, especially deposit taking, are also important. As MSEs 
grow, they generate small surpluses that can be reinvested or used to meet household needs. 
Case studies from nongovernment organization (NGO) microcredit programs in Supplementary 
Appendix 1 document the positive impact of microfinance on poverty reduction.

no  stock  market  and  only  a  few  insurance  companies.  Banking  sector  reforms  have  helped 
reduce the number of banks from 27 in 1998 to 14. Minimum capital requirements were raised 
from $300,000 in 1996 to $1.5 million for existing banks in 2001. To obtain a license, new banks 
need $3 million in charter capital. The banking sector continues to be dominated by four banks: 
Savingsbank,  Orionbank,5  Tajikevesheconombank,  and  Agroinvestbank,  which 
together 
accounted for 85% of banking sector assets as of November 2002. Overall, the banks have a 
particularly poor record in loan recovery: the four largest banks' nonperforming loans are equal 
to nearly 94% of their total portfolios. The smaller private banks do better, although still poorly 
by any measure, with 36% of their aggregate loan portfolios nonperforming.  
 
11. 
NBT has been strengthened but the financial position and operational efficiency of banks 
remain  weak.  The  Problem  Bank  Unit  has  been  established  in  NBT’s  Bank  Supervision

liquidated,  and 
Tajikvesheconombank,  Agroinvestbank,  and  Savingsbank  are  being  restructured.  The 
remaining  banks  cater  mostly  to  a  small  business  clientele  and  shareholder-related  interests. 
Savingsbank is wholly state owned, with other banks either completely privately owned or partly 
owned by ministries, state-owned enterprises, or state-owned farms. Only 8 of 14 banks meet 
the  $1.5-million  capital  requirement.  The  planned  increase  of  this  requirement  to  $3  million  is 
likely to lead to further closures. As of July 2002, 3 of 14 banks, accounting for only 12% of total 
banking sector assets, had met all prudential requirements and on the basis of waivers provided 
by NBT. 
 
12. 
In 2002 banking sector assets accounted for about 14% of GDP. The amount of lending 
to  the  cotton  sector  is  estimated  to  be  12%  of  GDP  (7%  in  1999).  Credit  to  the  non-cotton 
private sector represents barely 2% of GDP. The extreme and growing concentration of lending 
to the cotton sector, given its vulnerability to external price shocks, has a predictably deleterious 
effect  on  system-wide  loan  recovery.  Interest  rates  on  commercial  bank  loans  of  3–6-month 
tenor  average  25-30%  per  annum,  while  the  rates  on  3–6-month  term  deposits  are  close  to 
22%. The high deposit rates reflect the lack of public confidence in banks, which must offer high 
rates to the public and are, in turn, rewarded with little deposit activity. Rates on treasury bills 
average about 15%. NBT's discount rate for loans to commercial banks was 20% in February 
2003. Loans are mainly short term.  
 
13. 
Tajikistan suffers from the lowest degree of monetization among members of FSU. The 
deposit  base  of  banks  was  close  to  $28  million  at  the  end  of  2001,  equivalent  to  only  20%  of 
private  sector  credits,  compared  to  an  international  norm  of  around  120%  or  more.  Banks 
appear to be increasing their deposit taking, reflecting increased confidence in the currency, as 
well  as  positive  real  interest  rates.  The  volume  of  Tajik  workers'  remittances  flowing  in  from 
abroad  is  increasing.  Still,  the  overall  level  of  deposits  remains  low,  with  total  deposits 
equivalent  to  4%  of  GDP.6  The  banking  sector  has  yet  to  prove  itself  capable  of  mobilizing 
savings from the public and channeling loans to creditworthy borrowers.

6  These credit and deposit levels are in marked contrast to those of Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, with domestic

 4

 

 

The  Government  has  started  to  strengthen  confidence  in  the  banking  sector  by 
14. 
(i) increasing  the  minimum  capital  requirement  with  partial  holding  in  foreign  exchange, 
(ii) enforcing  full  loan  loss  provisioning,  (iii)  making  loan  loss  provisions  100%  tax  deductible, 
and  (iv)  assessing  tax  liabilities  of  banks  according  to  their  fixed  rather  than  total  assets. 
Continued rehabilitation, restructuring, and renovation of the banking subsector are critical and 
being supported by the World Bank and IMF.  
 

2. 

Nongovernment Organizations and Microfinance 

15. 
NGO  microcredit  activities  commenced  in  1993  with  the  Aga  Khan  Foundation  (AKF) 
through  its  Aga  Khan  Development  Network  (AKDN).  These  programs  have  focused  on 
humanitarian  relief  and  poverty  reduction  with  microcredit  as  a  component  of  more  diversified 
programs.  These  NGOs  have  been  financed  by  multilateral  and  bilateral  agencies,  and 
international NGOs, mostly on a grant basis. 
 
16. 
The country’s 17 microcredit programs mostly target the rural poor, mainly women and 
vulnerable groups. In most NGO microcredit programs, over 50% of clients, sometimes nearly 
100%, are women. Twelve programs include cash disbursements, and the rest provide credit in 
kind.  By  the  end  of  2001,  NGO  microcredit  programs  had  disbursed  cash  loans  of  more  than 
$6.6  million  to  44,000  borrowers7  and  had  an  aggregate  loan  portfolio  of  $3.0  million,  with  an 
average  borrower  balance  of  $94.  Around  20,000  more  families  receive  credit  in  kind.  The 
seven largest NGOs, each with a cash loan portfolio exceeding $100,000, account for 94% of all 
borrowers and 97% of total loans outstanding as of the end of 2001. The microfinance market is 
dominated  by  three  NGOs:  AKDN,  National  Association  of  Business  Women  in  Tajikistan 
(NABWT),  and  Agency  for  Technical  Cooperation  and  Development  (ACTED),  accounting  for 
nearly  80%  of  clients.  Four  NGOs  (AKDN,  NABWT,  ACTED,  and  the  Development  Fund) 
account for 85% of loans outstanding. Six of the larger NGOs had an aggregate 37% growth in 
clients and 79% growth in loan portfolio in 2001. While the aggregate NGO loan portfolio was 
equal to 6% of banking sector assets in 2001, it involved three times the number of households 
served by the banking sector.  
 
17. 
NGO credit programs serve far more customers than banks by offering microloans to the 
poor.  Most  microlending  is  to  groups:  95%  by  number  of  loans  and  75%  by  loan  amount. 
Lending  is  commonly  for  1–3  months  for  group-based  borrowers  and  12  months  for  individual 
borrowers.  Most  groups  have  7–12  members.  Individual-member  loan  size  within  groups  is 
usually $20–100, and for individuals, usually $300–$3,000, up to $5,000. Interest rates on group 
lending  are 2–4%  per month  and around  2% per  month  for  individual  lending.  Most  lending  is 
denominated in dollars but disbursed in somoni. Most lending is in the rural areas. Only three 
NGOs  lend  in  urban  areas,  and  mainly  to  groups.  Three  NGOs  have  achieved  loan  recovery 
rates higher than 98% of total lending. Loan loss rates in individual lending have been less than 
for group lending. Unlike banks, NGO credit programs have developed a culture of repayment 
among  clients.  The  high  rates  of  repayment  in  microfinance  also  demonstrate  that  the  credit 
products and underwriting standards and methodology used are appropriate. 
 
The collection of savings is common to many group lending programs, with saved funds 
18. 
accumulated within the groups and re-lent to members. Poor rural households, in groups, save 
TJS0.5–2.0  ($0.08–2.0)  each  per  month.  For  wealthier  households,  savings  of  TJS20  ($8.00) 
per month per person are common. One program has more than $53,000 in voluntary savings, 
and another, more than $15,000 in compulsory savings. 
                                                 
7Consultative Group on Assisting the Poorest (CGAP). 2002. Microfinance Sector Assessment. Tajikistan. 

  

 

 5

 
19.  Most  NGOs  serve  more  than  one  region.  Khatlon  accounts  for  47%  of  borrowers. 
Coverage, calculated as total borrowers divided by total households, is 5.3% in Khatlon, 4.6% in 
Republican  Subordination,  1.2%  in  Sughd,  and  30%  in  Gorno-Badakhshan  through  village 
organizations serviced by the AKDN. Loans outstanding from all NGOs total $600,000–900,000 
per region, underlining the relative lack of NGO credit programs throughout the country. 
 
C. 

Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Viable and Sustainable Institutions 

20. 
Tajikistan  has  a  relatively  young,  underdeveloped,  and  inefficient  financial  sector 
dominated  by  a  few  banks.  The  banking  subsector  and  the  smaller  set  of  unlicensed  and 
unregulated  NGOs  together  are  unable  to  meet  the  demand  for  basic  financial  services. 
Demand  for  financial  services  of  all  kinds  is  vast  and  unmet.  Rural  enterprises  and  farming 
households,  which  often  engage  in  a  variety  of  income-generating  on-  and  off-farm  activities, 
have  little  access  to  credit  due  to  limited  funds,  perceived  high  risk  of  agriculture  activity,  and 
high administration costs in making small loans. Savings mobilization, particularly in rural areas, 
is almost nonexistent.  
 
Assuming  that  20%  of  rural  and  10%  of  urban  households  make  up  the  market  for 
21. 
microfinance, at least 150,000 households, or nearly five times the present combined outreach 
of  all  NGO  microcredit  programs,  could  benefit  from  microfinance.  Most  rural  households  are 
without access to deposit services. Based on trends registered in the past two years by NGOs, 
an annual growth rate of 17.5% in numbers of households would yield an outreach of 150,000 
households in  10  years.  Satisfying  projected  loan  demand,  assuming  small  individual  loans  of 
$50–300, would require $25 million in new lending. Aggregate NGO microlending for 2001 was 
$3 million. Achieving an average household savings balance of $30 per year for 300,000 rural 
households  would  provide  a  rural  savings  balance  of  $9  million,  an  amount  equal  to  total 
domestic  currency  deposits  held  by  banks  in  2000.  Financial  service  providers  need  to  be 
encouraged to intensify efforts to provide services to this large potential market. 
 
Viable and sustainable financial institutions capable of providing basic financial services 
22. 
to  the  public  are  almost  completely  lacking.  None  of  the  NGOs  have  achieved  financial 
sustainability.  Inadequate  accounting,  portfolio,  and  management  information  systems  reflect 
weak  governance  and  internal  control.  Financial  intermediation  activities  are  inadequately 
separated from social ones with regard to financial reporting and staffing. The range of financial 
products is limited. The present volume of business is insufficient to allow for full cost recovery 
on  operations  and  the  creation  of  an  equity  base  out  of  profits.  Focus  on  organizational  and 
financial  planning  is  lacking.  Recently,  however,  three  NGOs  have  begun  to  become  more 
commercialized  and  specialized  microfinance  institution  (MFIs)  through  (i)  separation  of  head 
office  from  branch  operations,  (ii)  adoption  of  new  charts  of  accounts  to  produce  financial 
statements  that  relate  only  to  microfinance  activities,  (iii)  a  search  for  appropriate  accounting 
and  management  software,  (iv)  reorganization  of  departments  and  reallocation  of  staff,  (v) 
improvements  in  internal  controls  (particularly  internal  audit),  (vi)  separation  of  oversight  from 
operational functions, and (vii) a search for appropriate forms of legal entity and ownership. 
 
23. 
For  all  their  limitations,  NGOs  are  providing  the  bulk  of  rural  financial  services. 
Substantial trust already exists between NGOs and their customers, which is a sound basis for 
operation  expansion.  While  NGO  programs  have  institutional  weaknesses,  many  are  now 
examining ways to become commercially viable. Funds to expand lending, however, will need to 

 6

 

 

come  from  a  balanced  mix  of  deposit  mobilization,  borrowings,  and  equity  capital,  which  will 
only  be  attracted  by  an  appropriate  institutional  form,  maintenance  of  a  well-performing  loan 
portfolio,  and  close  and  responsive  ties  with  communities.  Market  demand  assumes  financial 
growth and customer outreach far in excess of the grant resources and/or loan financing likely 
to  be  made  available  to  NGOs  from  international  or  other  external  sources.  Therefore, 
intervention is warranted to develop a sustainable microfinance sector to expand access by the 
poor and rural dwellers to financial services.  
 

2. 

Policy on Microfinance 

24. 
The enabling environment for microfinance suffers from the absence of defined policies 
and  mechanisms,  hindering  NGO  microcredit  programs  from  becoming  commercially  viable 
providers of diversified financial services. The Government aims to create a formal microfinance 
sector,  in  which  some  NGO  microcredit  programs  will  be  transformed  into  licensed  and 
regulated MFIs. The development policy letter (Appendix 3) indicates the Government's strong 
support  for  the  creation  of  a  new,  fully  regulated  financial  subsector  free  of  the  enormous 
problems of the banks, and targeting most of the population with basic financial services. The 
policy  letter  recognizes  the  Government's  responsibility  to  establish  an  enabling  legal  and 
regulatory environment for microfinance and encourages NGOs to become regulated MFIs.  
 

3. 

Existing Legislation 

25. 
NGOs  are  registered  under  the  Law  on  Public  Organizations,  which  applies  only  to 
NGOs  supported  by  external  funding.  The  Law  on  State  Registration  of  Juridical  Persons  and 
Law on Joint Stock Companies cover the registration of various commercial and noncommercial 
entities, which depends on the form of organization and ownership. Individuals and enterprises, 
however, are required to register as a juridical person, and both are assumed to make a profit 
and  so  are  subject  to  a  variety  of  taxes.  Registration  as  a  noncommercial  entity,  which  would 
logically mean being exempt from profit or income tax (but not necessarily from other taxes), is 
generally  not  allowed.  Given  the  changing  status  of  legislation  for  registration,  and  the 
implications of registering as a commercial or noncommercial entity, it is not clear under which 
laws NGO credit programs should operate.  
 
26. 
Licensing of financial institutions is the responsibility of NBT. Whether NGOs operating 
microcredit programs should also be registered and licensed with NBT is unclear. As NGOs and 
MFIs will operate varying microfinance programs involving different levels of deposit, credit, and 
transfer  services,  a  classification  system  of  various  microfinance  organizations  with  relevant 
registration and licensing requirements and procedures is required. 
 
27. 
international 
agreements, thereby removing them from most legislation, including the Tax Code. But the legal 
and regulatory environment focuses on banks and does not provide for the legal establishment 
and  operation  of  NGO  microcredit  programs  and  potential  MFIs.  Laws  do  not  specifically 
recognize MFIs. They operate differently from other financial institutions, particularly commercial 
banks, and the legislation needs to reflect these differences.8  
 
28. 
The  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID)  and  International 
Finance  Corporation  (IFC),  in  close  consultation  with  ADB,  support  the  drafting  of  the  law  on

largely  under

comment to define the issues related to the legal framework of NGO credit programs and MFIs. 
 
29. 
In 1999 the new Tax Code was introduced. The country has 17 national and local taxes. 
Although  the  code  is  comprehensive,  assessment  and  frequency  of  collection  are  variable. 
Besides  efforts  to  draft  a  comprehensive  law  regularizing  and  governing  MFI  operations, 
disparate elements of the code that affect, or potentially affect, MFIs should be harmonized.  
 

4. 

Regulation and Supervision 

30.  While  the  reform  measures  have  reduced  the  number  of  banks,  ongoing  bank 
restructurings still burden the 32 NBT Supervision Department staff members, who must resolve 
issues of bank liquidations, bank mergers, and recapitalization; oversee installation and use of 
international  accounting  standards  (IAS)  in  all  banks;  improve  off-  and  on-site  monitoring 
systems  and  procedures;  and  deal  with  continuing  financial  and  management  weaknesses  of 
remaining  banks.  Supervision  is  made  more  difficult  by  the  large  number  of  bank  branches 
(130) and representative offices (over 130). To supervise MFIs, NBT will need more resources 
and  staff,  who  will  require  intensive  training.  Staff  will  need  to  develop  regulations  for  MFIs, 
license them, review and analyze regular reports received from them, and inspect them on site 
to enforce compliance with regulations.  
 
D. 

Lessons Learned 

31. 
ADB has considerable experience with microfinance operations in several countries but 
limited experience in the FSU transition economies, particularly in transforming NGO microcredit 
programs into licensed and regulated MFIs. MSDP will be ADB’s first experience with a broad 
sector  development  program  in  a  transition  economy.9  Lessons  are  drawn  from  ADB’s 
experience  in  rural  finance  from  transition  economies,  and  from  transformation  operations  in 
other countries. 
 
The lessons10 highlight the importance of (i) following a financial systems development 
32. 
approach to provide an enabling environment for commercial microfinance, (ii) focusing on poor 
clients to reduce poverty, (iii) working within the capacity of participating financial institutions to 
minimize distraction from their main functions and to avoid raising their administrative costs, and 
(iv) maximizing the impact of capacity building by providing TA over a period of time and not as 
an isolated instance. Because rural financial markets consist of different market segments with 
markedly diverse characteristics, a multiagency approach is necessary to meet different sectors’ 
demand for financial services.  
 
33. 
Kyrgyz Republic and Mongolia.11 Key lessons include the following:

A sound legal and regulatory environment is needed.  
The  growth  of  individual  savings  and  credit  unions  should  not  outpace  the 
capacity  of  apex  and  central  banks  to  train,  finance,  supervise,  and  regulate 
them.  
Long-term and effective capacity-building TA is needed.  
Quantitative  targets  should  focus  on  membership  size  rather  than  number  of 
institutions to limit proliferation of small nonviable institutions and take advantage 
of economies of scale. 

  
34. 
Some essential lessons are to be learned from the Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural 
Cooperatives Thailand, Village Bank (Unit Desa) of Bank Rakyat Indonesia, and the Grameen 
Bank Bangladesh. All are widely regarded as successful based on the criteria of outreach and 
self-sustainability12  due  to  (i)  favorable  macroeconomic,  agricultural,  and  rural  policies; 
(ii) adequate  investment  in  physical  and  social  rural  infrastructure;  (iii)  high  degree  of 
management  autonomy  in  operational  policy  formulation;  (iv)  staff  policies  that  stress  training, 
accountability, and reward through monetary incentives and promotion; (v) innovative, low-cost 
distribution systems, and mobile banking; (vi) innovative and flexible loan terms and conditions; 
(vii) close monitoring of loan performance, high collection rates, and low arrears; (viii) domestic 
savings mobilization as a growing source of funds, diminishing or eliminating the need for aid; 
(ix)  real  positive  and  often  relatively  high  on-lending  interest  rates  covering  costs;  and 
(x) administrative expense control. 
 
35. 
In  recent  years  a  number  of  NGOs  have  been  transformed  into  fully  licensed  and 
regulated  MFIs  providing  microcredit  services:  CARD  Bank  in  the  Philippines,  Association  of 
Cambodian  Local  Economic  Development  Agencies,  Bancosol  in  Bolivia,  and  XAC  Bank  in 
Mongolia.  The  key  factors  to  the  success  of  their  transformation  include  (i)  a  visionary 
management team, (ii) comprehensive staff development programs, (iii) adoption of accounting 
policies  and  practices  based  upon  international  standards,  (iv)  new  management  information 
systems to meet reporting requirements of regulators and/or supervisors and to track loans; and 
(v) development of new products and processes to meet demand. 
 
The  lessons  have  been  incorporated  into  the  design  of  MSDP  and,  where  possible, 
36. 
reinforced  through  the  policy  loan,  investment  loan,  and  TA.  The  design  is  flexible  to  allow 
introduction of the best practices during implementation.

The  World  Bank  is  providing  support  through  four  projects.  Under  the  Second 
Adjustment Credit, approved in 2001 for $35 million, the Government is adopting a wide-ranging 
reform  package  that  includes  strengthening  the  financial  sector  through  improved  banking 
supervision,  disclosure,  and  better  tax  treatment  of  banks.  The  Farm  Privatization  Support 
Project, approved in 1999, includes a component to pilot rural savings and credit associations in 
selected provinces to serve newly created private family farms. Support is provided for start-up

Project  is  scheduled  for  approval  in  late  2002.  It  aims  to  (i)  improve  the  regulatory  and 
enforcement mechanism for the evolution of competitive financial institutions; and (ii) develop a 
sustainable institutional mechanism for the provision of short-, medium-, and long-term credits 
for micro-, small, medium-sized, and large enterprises, and carry out case-by-case privatization.

MFIs.  The  Eurasia  Fund  will  continue  to  support  training  in  microfinance.  Future  international 
assistance  to  NGOs  is  expected  to  focus  on  skills  training,  support  for  the  startup  and 
development  of  NGO  programs  in  new  locations,  support  for  the  continuing  development  of 
NGO  systems,  and  lines  of  credit.  The  surge  in  external  funding,  however,  will  be  of  lasting 
benefit only if it supports the creation of sound and commercially viable MFIs. 
 
45.  While substantial resources are required to build the microfinance industry, and funding 
agencies  have  expressed  a  strong  desire  to  help,  coordination  among  them  is  also  important. 
They  thus  meet  and  are  in  constant  communication.  At  the  first  funding  agency  meeting  in 
February  2002,  they  agreed  that  ADB  would  lead  in  developing  the  legal  and  regulatory 
framework. The lead role in drafting the microfinance law then passed to USAID and IFC.  
 
F. 

Rationale 

46. 
Tajikistan  has  a  young  and  underdeveloped  financial  sector  that  cannot  meet  demand 
for  basic  financial  services.  NGOs  provide  the  bulk  of  financial  services,  particularly  in  rural 
areas.  NGOs  have  already  trained  a  large  number  of  groups  of  rural  people  in  basic  lending 
services, and to a more limited extent, in savings modalities. NGOs and Government, however, 
need to develop the capacity to manage and regulate formal MFIs. The policy, legal, regulatory, 
and  institutional  environment  is  not  appropriate  to  MFIs,  which  will  thus  be  unable  to  reach 
significant  scale  and  provide  financial  services  reliably  and  in  a  sustainable  manner. 
Government  and  externally  provided  funds  are  insufficient  to  meet  demand  for  microcredit. 
Institutional capacity to deliver financial services on a sustainable basis, including deposit-taking 
services,  is  needed.  MSDP  recognizes  that  the  bulk  of  MFI  resources  must  come  from  the 
economy  as  savings  mobilization  stimulated  through  sound,  sustainable,  and  regulated  MFIs. 
Therefore, an enabling environment is essential, as is the capacity of NGOs to be transformed 
into viable MFIs. 
 
47. 
To  foster  growth,  innovation,  and  diversity  of  financial  institutions,  including  MFIs,  a 
comprehensive  financial  systems  development  approach  is  required.  It  is  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s microfinance development strategy.17 The proposed MSDP is in line with the four pillars 
of  this  strategy:  (i)  creating  an  enabling  policy  environment;  (ii)  improving  the  financial 
infrastructure,  specifically  the  legal  and  regulatory  environment;  (iii)  building  the  institutional 
strength  of  MFIs  to  enhance  their  sustainability  and  outreach;  and  (iv)  encouraging  innovative 
programs that support the poor.  
 
                                                 
17 ADB. 2000. Finance for the Poor: Microfinance Development Strategy. Manila.

III. 

THE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 

A. 

Program Objectives and Scope 

The  goal  of  MSDP  is  to  create  a  strong,  commercially  viable  microfinance  sector.  The 
48. 
purpose  is  to  establish  a  regulated  microfinance  market  in  which  MSEs  and  poor  households 
have access to financial products provided through sustainable MFIs. The program framework 
is in Appendix 2. 
 
49. 
The components include (i) the adoption of policy, regulatory, and institutional actions to 
develop a microfinance industry; (ii) capacity building for NBT to regulate and supervise MFIs, 
and  for  NGOs  to  become  formally  licensed  and  regulated  MFIs;  and  (iii)  an  investment 
component  piloting  the  transformation  of  selected  NGO  microcredit  programs  into  formally 
licensed and regulated MFIs. 
 
B. 

Special Features 

50.  MSDP  will  take  steps  to  develop  microfinance  in  Tajikistan.  ADB  and  the  Government 
recognize  the  important  role  that  existing  NGO  microcredit  programs  can  play  in  developing 
financial  markets.  Specifically,  MSDP  will  help  the  Government  establish  a  comprehensive 
policy,  legal,  regulatory,  and  institutional  framework  to  develop  a  viable  and  sustainable 
industry.  This  is  of  particular  importance  in  a  country  recently  emerging  from  civil  war,  while 
adopting a reform agenda to move to a market-oriented system, where an enabling environment 
for  microfinance  does  not  yet  exist.  This  is  the  first  time  ADB  will  take  such  a  comprehensive 
approach in a transition economy (footnote 9). 
 
51.  MSDP is also involved with NGOs and their transformation into licensed and regulated 
MFIs.  Several  NGO  credit  programs  have  already  been  transformed  into  formal  financial 
the 
institutions.  While  ADB  has  supported  various  microfinance  programs, 
establishment of NGO microcredit programs, Grameen replicators, and creation of savings and 
credit  unions  systems,  ADB  has  not  exclusively  focused  on  transforming  NGOs  into  formal 
MFIs.  These  special  features  require  a  consultative  and  flexible  approach,  involving  all  key 
stakeholders.  
 
C. 

The Policy Loan 

including 

The policy loan requires the Government to implement a set of agreed-on measures to 
52. 
improve the operating environment for existing NGO microcredit programs and their subsequent 
transformation  into  licensed  and  regulated  MFIs.  The  Government’s  development  policy  letter 
and a policy matrix are in Appendixes 3 and 4, respectively. 
 

1. 

Objectives 

53. 
The  purpose  of  the  MSDP  policy  loan  is  to  create  a  legal,  regulatory,  and  supervisory 
environment  that  supports  the  development  of  a  strong,  commercially  viable  microfinance 
sector. This environment will allow for the establishment, operation, and growth of a diversified 
range  of  institutions  offering  microfinance  services.  These  institutions  could  include  those  that 
are  (i)  unregistered  and  unregulated,  (ii)  accredited  and  nonprudentially  supervised,  and  (iii) 
formally licensed and prudentially supervised.

2. 

Components and Outputs 

54. 
The  policy  loan  has  four  components,  outlined  below  with  their  expected  outputs  and 
summarized in a policy matrix (Appendix 4), which identifies monitoring mechanisms, identifies 
responsible agencies, and lists an implementation time frame. 
 

a. 

Policy and Strategy 

A government policy and strategy for microfinance development will provide a framework 
55. 
to establish an enabling environment. Policy and strategy should be comprehensive and include 
a sector agenda. The Government has submitted a policy letter to ADB as a condition for first 
tranche  release.  The  Government  will  keep  ADB  informed  of  policy  discussions  with  other 
multilateral  and  bilateral  aid  agencies  that  might  have  an  impact  on  the  program,  and  will 
provide  ADB  with  an  opportunity  to  comment  on  any  resulting  policy  proposals.  The 
Government will consider ADB’s  views before finalizing and implementing any such proposals. 
 

b. 

Legal Environment 

56. 
A number of laws will require revision to provide an appropriate framework to support the 
establishment and development of microfinance institutions. Under ADB TA 3555 (footnote 1) a 
legal  specialist  with  a  team  of  NBT  staff  reviewed  the  relevant  legislation  and  identified  a 
program  for  change.  Further  discussion  with  Government,  NBT,  NGOs,  and  other  funding 
agencies established the following requirements: 
 
Classification  of  Microfinance  Institutions.  A  classification  of  MFIs  should  be 
57. 
developed  to  clarify  the  status  of  all  NGO  microcredit  programs  and  future  MFIs,  and  issues 
related to registration and licensing, plus applicable legal and regulatory requirements. The draft 
microfinance  law  prepared  by  the  USAID/IFC  team  distinguishes  a  range  of  institutions 
providing  MF  services  and  establishes  the  legal  basis  for  (i)  microcredit  foundations,  and 
registered  NGO  microcredit  programs  that  make  microloans  with  funding  agencies  funds; 
(ii) microlending  companies,  which  are  licensed  and  registered,  have  commercial  funding 
sources but do not take deposits, and make microloans; and (iii) microcredit deposit companies, 
which take deposits from the public and make microloans.  
 
58. 
Adoption of a Microfinance Law. The draft law is being circulated for comment among 
stakeholders,  including  ADB,  and  is  expected  to  be  submitted  to  Parliament  for  approval  by 
June 2003. The draft law does not consider cooperatives, so a separate law on cooperatives will 
likely be necessary. 
 
59. 
Harmonizing of the Draft Microfinance Law with Relevant Laws. The final enactment 
of a microfinance law will require amendments to laws on the national bank of Tajikistan and on 
banks  and  banking  activities  to  (i)  provide  for  the  taking  of  savings  deposits  for  MFIs  from 
borrowers, members, and the public; (ii) clarify the application of the provision on licensing; and 
(iii) harmonize the microfinance law with other legislation. MSDP consulting services will ensure 
that the draft law is harmonized with relevant laws.

c. 

Regulation and Supervision 

62.

and  regulation  of  loan  societies  and  nonbank  financial  institution  generally.  These  regulations 
will  be  superseded  by  those  to  be  drafted  pursuant  to  the  draft  law.  It  provides  a  suitable 
general  framework  to  establish  MFIs,  lays  out  operational  parameters,  and  tasks  the  NBT  to 
develop regulations and supervise MFIs. A comprehensive set of prudential and nonprudential 
regulations,  readily  available  to  institutions  and  the  public,  will  be  prepared  for  all  institutions 
providing  microfinance  services.  The  regulations  should

63. 
NBT has limited resources as the sole regulatory agency. It must, however, develop the

64. 
An  effective  regulatory  and  supervisory  regime  should  be  developed  through  a 
consultative process involving policymakers and practitioners. Institutions should be established 
to oversee the development of the microfinance sector, including a microfinance policy steering

If the policy, legal, and regulatory environment is supportive of MFIs, then NGOs should

3. 

Amount of Loan, Terms, and Sources of Funds 

66. 
It  is  proposed  that  ADB  lend  the  Borrower  SDR2,934,000  ($4  million  equivalent)  from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources. The loan will have an amortization period of 24 years, including 
a  grace  period  of  8 years,  with  an  interest  charge  of  1.0%  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5% 
thereafter.  The  Borrower  will  not  relend  the  proceeds  of  the  program  loan.  The  funds  will  be 
transferred  from  ADB  to  the  Borrower  in  tranches.  The  policy  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to 
finance the foreign exchange cost of items produced and procured in ADB member countries, 
excluding listed ineligible items (Appendix 5). The counterpart funds will be used to finance the 
local  currency  costs  relating  to  the  implementation  of  certain  programs  and  other  activities 
consistent with the program objectives. 
 

 14

 

 

4. 

Implementation Arrangements 

67. 
Supported  by  the  MPSC,  NBT  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  cooperate  with  MOF, 
MOJ,  Office  of  the  President,  and  Ministry  of  State  Revenue  and  Duties  (MSRD)  on  the 
measures to be implemented. The MPSC will be chaired by a representative from NBT and will 
include  representatives  from  MOF,  MOJ,  MSRD,  and  Office  of  the  President.  The  MPSC  will 
meet at least quarterly to (i) ensure that the policies and actions in connection with the program 
set out in the policy letter and policy matrix are carried out on schedule; (ii) provide interagency 
coordination on important policy, legal, and regulatory issues related to the establishment and 
operation of MFIs; and (iii) facilitate the coordination and cooperation among the Government, 
NBT, NGOs, and funding agencies. NBT will have overall responsibility for (i) implementing the 
program, (ii) ensuring that reform measures are undertaken in line with the agreed-on timetable, 
(iii)  initiating  withdrawals  under  the  loan,  and  (iv)  allocating  and  monitoring  the  use  of 
counterpart  funds.  A  project  management  unit  (PMU)  established  in  NBT  will  support  ADB’s 
investment component and submit quarterly progress reports to ADB.  
 

a. 

Procurement and Disbursement  

68. 
Policy  loan  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  foreign  exchange  cost  of  items  produced 
and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries,  excluding  listed  ineligible  items  (Appendix  5) 
Disbursement  will  be  in  accordance  with  the  simplified  disbursement  procedures  and  related 
requirements for program loans. The Borrower will certify that (i) if loan proceeds finance goods 
already imported, the value of eligible imports in the period concerned will exceed the amount of 
the requested withdrawal; or (ii) if the loan proceeds finance items to be imported, the value of 
eligible imports in the immediately preceding one-year period will be equal to or greater than the 
amount of the requested withdrawal plus all other amounts expected to be withdrawn during the 
succeeding one-year period. ADB will retain the right to audit the use of loan proceeds and to 
verify  the  accuracy  of  the  Borrower’s  certificate.  Before  withdrawal,  the  Borrower  will  open  a 
deposit account with a bank to be agreed on with ADB in which all funds will be deposited. The 
account will be managed in accordance with terms satisfactory to ADB. 
 

b. 

Monitoring and Tranching   

69. 
The policy loan will be released in two tranches. The first, $1.5 million equivalent, will be 
released upon loan effectiveness, before which the Government must initiate certain institutional 
and policy actions to demonstrate its commitment to reform: (i) release the policy statement on 
microfinance,  (ii)  issue  a  presidential  decree  establishing  the  MPSC,  and  (iii)  issue  a 
presidential decree establishing the TWG. 
 
70. 
The  Government  will  ensure  that  NBT  (i)  monitors  the  implementation  of  the  program 
and its impacts, and (ii) submits to ADB  quarterly reports on the implementation of the policy 
matrix, including accomplishment of the measures set forth in the policy letter and policy matrix. 
The  Borrower  and  ADB  will  review  the  implementation  of  the  Program  every  six  months,  and 
assess  the  impact  of  all  relevant  reforms  in  the  financial  and  social  security  sectors,  labor 
markets, and the economy in general.  
 
71. 
ADB will undertake an interim review of MSDP before the release of the second tranche. 
It will be $2.5 million equivalent and is expected to be released within 24 months of the effective 
date, provided that (i) the Government will have enacted the draft law; (ii) in close consultation 
with  ADB,  MPSC,  and  TWG,  the  Government  will  have  reviewed  and  amended  the  tax 
legislation to establish a taxation environment supportive of the establishment and development 

  

 

 15

of  MFIs;  (ii)  the  Government  will  have  caused  NBT  to  develop  and  adopt  prudential  and 
nonprudential  regulations  to  supervise  diversified  categories  of  MFIs;  and  (iv)  NBT  will  have 
issued operating licenses to at least two deposit-taking MFIs.  
 
ADB will also consider the provision of an incentive tranche of $1 million equivalent to be 
72. 
released  up  to  six  months  before  the  second  tranche  if  the  draft  law  has  been  ratified  by 
Parliament, and regulations for MFIs approved by NBT. 
 
D. 

Investment Loan 

1. 

Objectives 

The purpose of the MSDP investment loan is to expand the outreach and sustainability 
73. 
of  MFIs  serving  MSEs  and  poor  households  by  transforming  unregulated  credit  programs  to 
licensed, regulated financial institutions. By the end of the project it is expected that (i) at least 
two deposit-taking MFIs will be operating in full compliance with all regulatory requirements; (ii) 
MFI  outreach  will  have  increased  by  100%,  with  about  75%  of  clients  being  initially  poor,  and 
50% being women; (iii) MFI savings deposits will reach about 10% of loans outstanding; (iv) MFI 
loans  outstanding  will  reach  about  TJS9  million  ($3.5  million);  and  (v)  MFI  loan  losses  will  be 
less than 4%. 
 

2. 

Components and Outputs 

74. 
The  project  scope  has  four  components:  (i)  regulatory  framework,  (ii)  establishment  of 
MFIs,  (iii)  institutional  strengthening,  and  (iv)  project  management.  The  project  scope  is 
nationwide,  with  geographical  focus  on  locations  where  selected  NGOs  willing  to  transform  to 
MFIs have existing microfinance programs. 
 

a. 

Regulatory Framework 

75. 
A legal and regulatory environment favorable to MFI operations is a prerequisite to the 
formation of legally registered and licensed MFIs. By agreement, USAID and IFC are providing 
TA to prepare the draft law. Through this component, ADB will focus on developing regulations 
and  increasing  community  awareness  of  all  laws  and  regulations,  and  MFI  activities. 
Regulations  will  be  prepared  through  a  consultative  process  with  key  stakeholders,  largely 
conducted  through  the  TWG,  comprising  Government,  NBT  and  NGO  representatives  (para. 
99).  

b. 

Establishment of Microfinance Institution 

76. 
In  parallel  with  the  development  of  a  favorable  legal  and  regulatory  environment,  the 
project will focus on the transformation of selected NGO microcredit programs into licensed and 
regulated MFIs. The project will work with existing NGO credit programs that have (i) registered 
as a local NGO, (ii) at least three years experience in Tajikistan providing credit, (iii) at least one 
year’s experience in delivering cash credit to groups and/or individuals, (iv) loan losses of less 
than 4%, and (v) a willingness and capacity to meet the licensing and regulation requirements to 
be  defined  by  NBT  regulations.  These  and  other  criteria  for  selecting  NGO  programs  will  be 
subject to government and ADB approval. Graduation programs for selected NGO programs will 
be developed. 
 
77. 
The  project  will  work  with  selected  NGOs  to  establish  institutional  forms.  NGOs  will 
become  either  shareholder-owned  institutions  or  member-owned  institutions  such  as  savings 

 16

 

 

and credit unions. With advice and assistance from the project, NGOs will decide on the type of 
institutional  form  to  adopt.  The  project  will  help  NGOs  prepare  business  plans,  strategies, 
systems  and  procedures,  and  operating  standards  to  transform  and  operate  an  MFI.  During 
transformation,  NGOs  will  provide  regularly  updated  reports  on  their  operations,  performance, 
and status of transformation. Financial and management reporting and internal controls will be 
consistent with Consultative Group on Assisting the Poorest (CGAP) guidelines. 
 
78. 
Once  the  MFI  is  licensed  it  will  be  eligible  for  a  credit  line  initially  for  one  year  and 
subsequently for up to 10 years, depending on performance, subject to credit-line participation 
criteria  specified  below.  MFIs  will  also  have  to  develop  diversified  savings  and  loan  products 
and  other  services.  As  the  project  will  focus  on  savings,  it  will  emphasize  development  of  at 
least two savings products such as passbook accounts and term deposits for all MFIs.  
 
79. 
The  project  will  also  explore  promoting  and  establishing  microfinance  services  in  rural 
areas through commercial banks. The possibility of a partner arrangement between MFIs and a 
commercial bank will be considered. 
 
80. 
Established  MFIs  will  be  in  the  early  stage  of  developing  credit  and  savings  services. 
MFIs will have little credibility with commercial banks and may have difficulty obtaining financing 
through  them.  Since  deposit  mobilization  must  be  backed  by  adequate  liquidity  or  access  to 
liquidity,  appropriate  liquidity  mechanisms  are  required.  To  provide  sufficient  liquidity  under 
normal  operations,  MFIs  will  be  expected  to  hold  a  portion  of  their  assets  in  near-liquid  form, 
probably  on  term  deposit  with  a  reputable  bank.  So  that  sufficient  funds  are  available  for 
unexpected customer withdrawals, a pilot liquidity guarantee fund (LGF) should be established 
to  provide  short-term  funds  to  MFIs  on  terms  similar  to  the  refinance  facility  provided  through 
NBT  for  commercial  banks.  An  LGF  of  $100,000  equivalent  will  be  financed  in  equal  parts  by 
the Government/NBT and ADB.  
 
To be eligible to draw down against LGF, MFIs must comply with NBT regulations and 
81. 
maintain standard levels of liquidity before the need for funds. Based on the amount of savings 
and paid-up capital, the amount an MFI can draw on will be limited, with a draw-down up to 90 
days. LGF should be able to make funds available within 24 hours. LGF operational procedures 
will  be  prepared  and  agreed  on  by  the  Government/NBT,  ADB,  and  NGOs/MFIs.  Further 
development or dissolution will be agreed on at project completion. 
 

c. 

Institutional Strengthening 

82.  While NGOs have been operating credit programs in Tajikistan since 1995, Government 
and NGOs have limited experience in supervising and operating MFIs. Before, during, and after 
NGO programs become MFIs, relevant training must be provided to NBT and NGOs/MFIs.  

83.  While  NBT  has  experience  in  supervising  banks,  it  does  not  have  the  capacity  and 
expertise  to  supervise  MFIs.  Their  supervision  will  be  the  responsibility  of  the  Supervision 
Department  for  banks.  To  strengthen  NBT,  the  project  will  support  the  establishment  of 
supervision  capacity  by  hiring  two  more  staff;  providing  training  in  accounting,  legal,  and 
regulatory  issues,  and  on-site  supervision  of  MFIs;  and  providing  a  study  course  abroad  in 
microfinance  and  supervision.  Supervision  methods  will  be  reviewed  and  modified  for  MFIs. 
New procedures will be introduced and operating manuals prepared. NBT will then be expected 
to effectively monitor MFIs off site and supervise them on site. 

  

 

 17

The transformation of NGO programs into MFIs will require substantial training to ensure 
84. 
that  staff  have  the  capability  to  manage  and  operate  a  licensed  and  fully  regulated  financial 
institution. Head office staff, branch managers, and field supervisors will have to be trained in a 
range of areas. At the field level, training will be on the job and supported by operation manuals. 
NGOs  have  their  own  approaches  to  training  but  all  training  must  provide  staff  with  the  skills 
required.  The  project  will  support  the  preparation  of  operating  procedures  and  manuals,  and 
assess approaches for a system of incentive payments for good staff performance. 

Training  courses  will  be  organized  following  an  annual  consultation  by  the  training 
85. 
specialist  to  determine  the  progressive  needs  of  MFIs.  The  courses  will  include  asset/liability 
management  and  risk  identification  and  mitigation;  product  development  and  pricing;  staff 
management,  performance  measurement,  and  provision  of 
loan  portfolio 
management; and governance and internal controls. Each course will last 6–12 days, have 15–
20 participants, and will cover 120 trainees. MFIs will meet the travel and per diem costs of the

deposits, other MFIs will also be eligible to participate in domestic training programs.

Implementation Arrangements 

a. 

Organization and Management Arrangements 

94. 

The project management arrangements comprise the MPSC, PMU, and TWG.  

95. 
The  MPSC  will  comprise  representatives  of  NBT  (chair),  Office  of  the  President,  MOF, 
MOJ,  MSRD,  project  director  (NBT),  NGOs  (two  representatives),  and  other  agencies  as 
required.  The  project  manager  will  act  as  secretary.  ADB  and  other  funding  agencies  will 
participate  as  observers.  The  MPSC  will  (i)  provide  intergovernmental  agency  coordination  on 
important  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  issues  related  to  the  establishment  and  operation  of 
MFIs; and (ii) facilitate the coordination and cooperation between the Government, NBT, NGOs, 
and funding agencies. The two NGO representatives will be selected by the NGO community. 
The  MPSC  will  meet  quarterly  during  the  first  12  months  of  the  project  and  semiannually 
thereafter,  unless  circumstances  require  more  frequent  meetings.  The  establishment  of  the 
MPSC will be a condition for loan effectiveness.  

96. 
The  executing  agency  will  be  NBT.  It  will  (i)  coordinate  the  project;  (ii)  maintain 
appropriate  accounts,  including  records  on  withdrawal  applications  and  disbursements; 
(iii) ensure  that  procurement  is  managed  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines;  (v)  prepare  and 
submit  quarterly  progress  and  other  reports  in  formats  and  content  agreed  on  with  ADB; 
(vi) ensure  timely  submission  of  audited  accounts  of  the  project  to  ADB;  and  (vi)  serve  as  the 
focal  point  for  ADB’s  project  review  and  administration  activities  and  between  ADB  and 
NGOs/MFIs. 

97. 
NBT  will  appoint  a  project  director.  This  position  is  a  half-time  unfunded  position, 
nominated  by  NBT  and  approved  by  the  MPSC.  The  project  director  will  be  responsible  for 
coordinating  project  implementation,  and  will  countersign  with  the  project  manager  withdrawal 
applications and disbursement documents. The project director will be appointed as a condition 
of loan negotiations. 

98. 
The  PMU  will  host  the  project  manager,  domestic  and  international  consultants,  and 
other office support staff (secretary/office administrator, interpreters, and drivers). The PMU will 
serve  the  needs  of  other  funding  agency  projects  (specifically  the  World  Bank's  small  and 
medium-sized enterprise credit line) and provide support to MSDP. The project manager will be 
a  full-time  domestic  consultant,  who  will  (i)  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  implementation 
activities,  (ii)  supervise  consultants,  and  (iii)  be  responsible  and  report  to  the  project  director. 
The  PMU  will  (i)  ensure  that  the  project  is  implemented  in  accordance  with  the  design; 
(ii) ensure  effective  coordination  of  all  activities  and  the  state  and  local  agencies  and  NGOs 
involved; 
records  on  withdrawal  applications  and

quarterly progress and other reports in formats agreed on with ADB; and (vi) provide support to 
the  MPSC  and  TWG.  The  Government  and  NBT  will  ensure  that  adequate  office  space  with

TWG  which  includes  the  Government,  NBT,  NGO  and  MFI  will  be  composed  of  the 
project  director  (chair);  legal,  regulatory  and  supervision,  and  foreign  investment  staff  of  NBT; 
MOF, MOJ, and the Office of the President; NGOs/MFIs (two representatives); project manager

appoints an alternate staff for each NBT staff in the TWG. The Government will also ensure that

and ADB. 

b. 

Relending and On-lending Terms and Conditions 

100.  The Borrower will be the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan. It will bear (i) the full 
foreign exchange risk of the total amount of the loans, and (ii) responsibility to repay the ADB 
loans.  ADB  will  lend  SDR2,934,000  of  the  investment  loan  component  to  the  Borrower.  The 
Borrower through a subsidiary loan agreement acceptable to ADB will relend funds in somoni at 
0%  interest  rate  to  NBT.  These  loan  funds  will  be  used  by  NBT  for  (i)  institutional  capacity 
building of NBT, which will be entirely responsible for repayments to the Borrower; and (ii) on-
lending  to   participating  commercial  banks  (PCBs),  which  will  assume  the  credit  risk.  NBT  will 
on-lend  the  proceeds  of  the  credit  line  in  somoni  to  PCBs  at  a  rate  not  less  than  NBT's 
published  discount  or  refinancing  rate,  which  will  be  positive  in  real  terms  and  acceptable  to 
ADB. PCBs will further on-lend credit-line proceeds to MFIs and subborrowers at market-based 
interest rates that take into account PCB’s cost of funds and administrative expenses, adding a 
reasonable risk premium to cover potential losses. PCBs will enter into credit agreements with 
MFIs or subborrowers. MFIs will be PCBs’ subborrowers. MFIs will on-lend to MSEs at market-
based  interest  rates  that  take  into  account  MFI’s  cost  of  funds  and  administrative  expenses, 
plus a reasonable risk premium to cover potential losses.18 MFIs will bear the credit risk for their 
on-lending. Implementation arrangements related to the credit line will be reviewed jointly by the 
Government,  ADB,  PCBs,  and  MFIs  at  least  once  every  six  months,  and  the  arrangements 
adjusted accordingly. Appendix 7 presents a diagram of the investment loan fund flow.  
 
101. 
Initially, a PCB may borrow up to $500,000 equivalent for one year. If loan repayment is 
satisfactory,  and  the  PCB  continues  to  meet  qualification  criteria  governing  commercial  bank 
participation in MSDP, the PCB may borrow up to $1 million equivalent for 10 years. PCBs may 
use funds borrowed from NBT solely for on-lending to MFIs and subborrowers, and PCBs must 
demonstrate  to  the  satisfaction  of  NBT  and  ADB  that  credit-line  proceeds  are  fully  on-lent  to 

                                                 
18  NGOs  lend  in  somoni  with  repayments  indexed  to  the  dollar,  thus  transferring  the  foreign  exchange  risk  to  the 

borrower. 

  

 

 21

eligible MFIs within 3 working days. If a PCB is found not to have complied with the qualification 
criteria, the PMU and NBT, with the prior approval of ADB, will determine whether the PCB will 
(i) prepare and implement a plan of action to comply, or (ii) be excluded from the project credit 
line. Any PCB not complying for more than one quarter will be excluded from the project. The 
excluded  PCB  will  pay  back  to  the  project  all  funds  made  available  through  the  project.  The 
PCB may not accelerate or otherwise require the MFIs to repay the corresponding subloans but 
must  use  other  sources  of  funds  to  repay  NBT,  so  long  as  the  MFIs  have  complied  with  the 
relevant MSDP participation criteria. Appendix 12 presents the PCB participation criteria. NBT, 
through  the  PMU,  will  monitor  PCB  financial  performance  and  ongoing  compliance  with  the 
participation criteria. 
 
102. 
Initially, an MFI may borrow up to $250,000 equivalent for one year. If loan repayment is 
satisfactory on the initial loan and the MFI continues to meet the eligibility requirements, it may 
borrow up to $500,000 for ten years. MFIs may use funds borrowed from PBCs under the credit 
line  solely  for  on-lending  to  MSEs  or  individuals,  or  for  the  purchase  of  fixed  assets,  with  the 
MFI subject to the following borrowing limits: (i) at no time  will the MFI's ratio of total loans to 
assets be less than 70%; (ii) at no time will the ratio of the MFI's credit-line borrowings to total 
loans  be  greater  than  50%;  (iii)  at  no  time  will  the  ratio  of  the  MFI’s  fixed  to  total  assets  be 
greater than 10%. If an MFI is found not to have complied with the eligibility criteria or any of the 
three  borrowing  limits,  the  PCB,  in  consultation  with  the  PMU  and  NBT,  and  with  the  prior 
approval  of  ADB,  will  determine  whether  the  MFI  concerned  will  (i)  prepare  and  implement  a 
plan  of  action  to  comply,  or  (ii)  be  excluded  from  the  project  credit  line.  Any  MFI  that  has  not 
complied  for  more  than  one  quarter  will  be  excluded  from  the  project  and  pay  back  all  funds 
received through the project. The PCB must repay the same amount to NBT under the PCB’s 
corresponding loan within 3 working days. In addition to the PCBs, NBT, through the PMU, will 
monitor MFI financial performance, and compliance with eligibility criteria.  
 
103.  PCBs and MFIs will maintain accounting systems and records in accordance with local 
accounting standards acceptable to ADB for financial institutions, and will be subject to review 
by ADB missions. PCB and MFI financial and accounting operations are subject to annual audit 
by external auditors acceptable to ADB.  
 
104.  As the legal and regulatory enabling environment is being constructed, and while NGOs 
are  transformed  through  this  evolving  environment,  the  system  of  fund  disbursement  via  the 
credit  line  will  be  examined  and  streamlined.  Disbursements  of  the  credit  line  will  begin  only 
after  18–24  months,  during  which  time  MSDP  project  staff  and  consultants  will  analyze 
candidate PCBs, using the participation criteria in Appendix 12. 
 
105.  A key objective of MSDP is to help experienced NGO credit programs become licensed 
MFIs, subject to NBT regulation and supervision. Only after a license has been issued and the 
NGO program legally transformed into an MFI will it be eligible to access the credit line. 
 

c. 

Eligibility Criteria for Participating Commercial Banks 

106.  MSDP  will  qualify  commercial  banks  to  access  the  credit  line  for  on-lending  to  MFIs. 
MSDP  project  staff  and  consultants  will  determine  financial and  operating  soundness  of  PCBs, 
as  well  as  judge  their  capacity  to  analyze  the  credit  risk  of  MFIs.  To  participate  in  the  MSDP 
credit-line component, a PCB must at least be (i) legally licensed; (ii) in compliance with all NBT 
prudential requirements; (iii) rated satisfactory according to NBT on-site examination reports for 
the  most  recent  two  calendar  years;  (iv)  profitable  for  the  past  two  calendar  years  as 
demonstrated  by  externally  audited  financial  statements  prepared  in  IAS  format;  (v)  properly 

 22

 

 

capitalized,  with  capital  relative  to  risk-weighted  assets  of  not  less  than  15%;  (vi)  profitable,  as 
measured by return on average assets for the past two calendar years of at least 2%; (vii) in full 
compliance with recommended loan classification and loan provisioning requirements; (viii) able 
to demonstrate capacity to analyze credit risk of MFIs; and (ix) be in compliance with additional 
criteria  as  recommended  by  the  PMU,  NBT,  MPSC,  and  TWG,  and  approved  by  ADB.  Should 
the PCB also meet criteria (iii) and (iv) set out for MFI accreditation in para. 107, the PCB may be 
allowed  to  borrow  funds  for  on-lending  directly  to  MSEs  and  individuals  or  for  fixed-asset 
purchases, subject to (i) approval by NBT and ADB, and (ii) compliance with the three financial 
ratio limits defined in para. 108. See Appendix 12 for further discussion of criteria for participation 
in  MSDP  by  commercial  banks,  including  recommended  loan  classification  and  provisioning 
requirements, as well as a complete list of NBT prudential requirements.  
 

d. 

Eligibility Criteria for Microfinance Institutions 

107.  MSDP  will  qualify  MFIs  to  participate  in  the  credit  line.  MSDP  project  staff  and 
consultants  will  determine  financial  and  operating  soundness,  as  well  as  judge  the  capacity  of 
MFIs  to  manage  the  credit  risk  of  on-lending  to  MSEs  and  individuals.  At  a  minimum,  to  be 
eligible for participation to the project, an MFI must (i) be legally licensed; (ii) comply with all NBT 
prudential requirements for MFIs; (iii) have a ratio of average loan size to GDP per capita of not 
more than 200%; (iv) have at least 50% women borrowing clients; (v) have achieved operational 
self-sufficiency;  (vi)  have  capital  relative  to  risk-weighted  assets  of  15%;  (vii)  be  fully  in 
compliance  with  recommended  loan  classification  and  loan  provisioning  requirements;  (vi) 
possess  demonstrable  capacity  to  analyze  and  manage  credit  risk  of  MSEs  and  individual 
borrowers;  and  (vii)  comply  with  additional  criteria  recommended  by  PMU,  NBT,  MPSC,  and 
TWG, and approved by ADB. See Appendix 13 for a discussion of MSDP participation criteria for 
MFIs. Once the MFI has been determined to be eligible, it may approach, or may be approached 
by,  a  PCB.  Before  on-lending  by  a  PCB  to  an  MFI,  the  PCB  will  analyze  the  MFI.  If  the  PCB 
decides to lend to the MFI, the PCB will assume the full credit risk of lending to the MFI. PCBs 
will  enter  into  credit  agreements  with  MFIs,  which  will  be  reviewed  in  advance  by,  and  be 
acceptable in form and substance to, NBT and ADB. The credit agreement will require the PCB 
to incorporate at a minimum MSDP participation criteria for MFIs. 
 

e. 

Implementation Schedule 

108.  The project will be implemented over 4 years from the time the loan agreement becomes 
effective, and the loan will be completely drawn down within 5 years. Project implementation will 
commence  in  2003.  The  pilot  nature  of  MFI  transformation,  the  continuing  reforms  in  the 
financial sector, and the relative inexperience in transforming NGO programs into MFIs require 
a flexible approach. However, more flexibility will require the Government and ADB to focus on 
project monitoring and supervision.  

f.

international and 72 person-months of domestic expertise will be recruited under the investment

person-months), computer systems specialist (8 person-months), training specialist (10 person-
months),  and  accountant  (6  person-months).  International  consultants  will  be  a  microfinance 
sector  specialist/team  leader  (7  person-months),  regulatory  and  supervision  specialist  (5 
person-months),  and  accounting  and  management  information  systems  specialist  (2  person-
months). All consultants will report to the project manager.  Terms of reference for consultants

h. 

Disbursement 

112.  The Borrower will establish an imprest account in NBT to facilitate the timely release of 
loan  funds  and  pay  for  all  project  expenditures,  including  credit-line  operations.  The  imprest 
account  will  be  established  immediately  after  loan  effectiveness.  The  initial  amount  to  be 
deposited into the imprest account will not exceed $250,000 equivalent. The project director will 
operate  the  imprest  account  in  accordance  with  the  procedures  established  by  NBT  and  the 
Government.  All  withdrawal  applications  will  be  signed  by  the  project  director  and  project 
manager.  The  EA  will  maintain  an  accounting  system  and  accounting  records  in  accordance 
with  local  accounting  standards  acceptable  to  ADB  (and  subject  to  regular  reviews  by  ADB 
missions). ADB’s statement of expenditure (SOE) procedure will be used to reimburse eligible 
expenditures  and  to  liquidate  advances  provided  to  the  imprest  account.  Individual  payments 
that  may  be  reimbursed  or  liquidated  under  the  SOE  procedure  will  not  exceed  $25,000 
equivalent, and the imprest account and SOE procedure will be established and maintained in 
accordance  with  the  Loan  Disbursement  HandBook  and  detailed  arrangements  between  the 
Government  and  ADB.  To  liquidate  and  replenish  the  imprest  account,  the  EA  is  required  to 
submit  to  ADB  (i)  a  list  of  approved  loan  applications  and  their  amounts,  and  (ii)  the  amount 
released to PCBs and/or MFIs. 

i. 

Accounts, Audit, and Report

Government  will  have  such  accounts  and  related  financial  statements  audited  annually  by 
auditors  acceptable  to  ADB  and  in  accordance  with  provisions  of  the  loan  agreement  and 
Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by 
ADB. The imprest account and SOE records will also be audited as part of the annual audit. The 
Government  will  submit  to  ADB  certified  copies  in  English  of  such  audited  accounts  and 
financial  statements  and  the  reports  of  the  auditors,  within  six  months  after  the  close  of  each 
financial  year.  In  compliance  with  the  requirement  for  annual  audited  financial  statements,

proceeds  of  this  loan  may  be  used  to  finance  expenditure  for  private  sector  auditors  and 
translations of auditors’ reports into English. 

114.  NBT  will  submit  consolidated  quarterly  progress  reports  to  ADB,  in  English,  on  all 
aspects  of  project  implementation.  The  reports  will  include  details  on  overall  progress  in 
implementation and problems/issues encountered during the reference period, measures taken

framework; and to assess the project’s technical, social, and economic effects. NBT will submit 
to ADB a quarterly monitoring report on progress towards achieving the project objectives. 

k. 

Project Reviews 

117.  Two  loan  reviews  will  be  conducted  in  the  first  year  of  implementation.  Semiannual 
reviews will continue until annual reviews are considered sufficient for effective administration. A 
more  comprehensive  review  of  the  project  will  be  carried  out  by  the  Government,  NBT, 
NGOs/MFIs, and ADB after 18 months to assess project performance and the need for changes 
in design and implementation. 

IV. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

A. 

Objectives 

118.  The  goal  of  the  TA  is  to  build  strong,  commercially  viable  MFIs  capable  of  providing 
financial  services  to  MSEs  and  poor  households  while  developing  strong  regulatory  and 
supervisory  institutions  to  support  MFIs.  The  purpose  is  to  (i)  strengthen  the  supervisory 
capacity  of  NBT  to  oversee  MFIs,  and  (ii)  develop  the  capacity  of  MFIs  to  operate  as 
commercially viable financial institutions.  

B. 

Scope 

119.  The  TA  will  (i)  formulate  MFI  financial  models  that  feasibly  fit  microfinance  needs  and 
NGO capabilities; (ii) work closely with each MFI and candidate MFI in planning, evaluation of 
activities,  development  of  new  financial  products,  improvement  of  governance  and  internal 
controls, and development of staff benefit packages linked to staff performance; (iii) work closely 
with  the  NBT  MFI  supervision  section  in  refining  off-site  monitoring  and  appraisal  of  MFIs; 
(iv) work with NBT staff in developing efficient and effective procedures for on-site inspections; 
(v) explore possible linkages between commercial banks and MFIs in the joint development of 
products, placing of deposits, credit lines, and equity investment; (vi) prepare a baseline survey 
of  MFI  customers  and  a  system  for  monitoring  benefits  received  by  households  during  the 
project; and (vii) obtain market information from households concerning demand for a range of 
financial services.  

120.  Training  and  study  tours  abroad  will  be  provided  to  improve  the  capacity  of  NBT  and 
senior  MFI  staff.  Two  staff  from  the  NBT  MFI  supervision  section  will  undergo  a  three-week 
study tour of countries that have been successful in developing a MF sector. Eight managers of 
MFIs  will  be  helped  to  attend  formal  courses  in  MF  covering  (i)  governance  and  internal 
controls, (ii) product development and pricing, (iii) asset and liability management, including risk 
management, and (iv) planning and appraisal of programs.  

121.  NBT will provide office space and facilities for 28 person-months of consulting services 
over  three  years.  International  expertise  includes  an  MFI  specialist  (15  person-months)  and  a 
social  economist  (4  person-months).  A  domestic  product  development  specialist  (6  person-
months)  will  also  be  recruited.  Three  months  of  consulting  service  are  unallocated  in  case  of 
unexpected requirements. The terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 8.

123.  NBT  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA.  The  consultants  will  be  part  of  the  PMU
